info.title: IRIS
info.description:
## IRIS API 
To use these API endpoint, an API key is needed and can be found in every user profile under `My settings` > `API Key`. 
This specification applies to v2.1.0 > Iris > v2.3.7. The supported API version can be checked in `Advanced` > `Server settings` > `Server versions` on IRIS.   
The API port is the same as the one used for the web interface, so `443` by default.  
 
## Changes
### Changes in v2.0.0
This version introduces access control. Every request now needs to have the `cid=x` parameter in the URI.  
Deletion endpoints have been migrated from `GET` to `POST`. Deletion GET endpoints have been marqued as `deprecated` and are not available anymore.  

### Changes in v1.4.5
v1.4.5 introduced the concept of custom attributes. These JSON objects that are stored into almost all case objects such as Assets, IOCs, etc. They are defined by administrators or modules and can vary from one objet to another despite being of the same type.  Because of this, no definitive structure can be expected from these fields. They are all named ``custom_attributes``.

data.description: CRC32 of the summary

post.description:
Update the summary of a case. Carefull: this will trigger an overwrite of the summary. Summaries are shared interactively between users. If an update summary is issued, every user will receive the change and their locale changes will be lost.  
The summary is a markdown-compatible text.

Add a task log to the case. The task log is registered under Activities and is be availble in reports templating. 
If CID is omitted, the default case of the calling user is used.

get.description:
Export a case in JSON format including all the information such as assets, iocs, etc. This request can take a very long time depending on the size of the case.  
The datastore is not part of the response and needs to be requested manually.

parameters.name: cid
parameters.description: ID Of the case to export

responses.description: A full export of the case without the files in the datastore

timeline.event_content: First time ever Bob logging observed from 82.223.70.24 on VPN

get.description: The endpoint is deprecated. Use `case/timeline/advanced-filter`.

Filter the timeline through a query. `q` should be a valid JSON mapping `{field1:[value], field2: [value2]}`.  
Fields are AND together. The query needs to be URL encoded.  

The following fields are available:   

- asset: Asset linked to the event
- ioc: IOC linked to the event
- tag: Tag within the event
- title: Title of the event
- description: Description of the event
- raw : Raw event content
- category: Category of the event
- source: Source of the event
- startDate: Start date to filter with
- endDate: End date to filter with
The endpoint is deprecated. Use `case/timeline/advanced-filter`.
Fetch the state of the timeline.

get.description: This endpoint is depreacted. Use `/dim/tasks/list/`

List all manual hooks available for a particular case object.  
Available objects types are : 

- case
- ioc 
- asset
- note
- event
- task 
- evidence 
- global_task 

The returned information can provided to the ``/dim/hooks/call`` endpoint to trigger a hook.

post.description:
Executes a manual trigger on a specified hook. This allows to trigger a hook as it would be done on the GUI. This only concerns manual hooks, and each call triggers a specific hook of a specific module, as specified in the request. 

To get a list of all available hooks for a case object, use the ``/dim/hooks/options/<type>/list`` endpoint.

hook_name.description: Internal name of the hook as specified in the hook documentation.

module_name.description: Name of the module to call

hook_ui_name.description: UI name of the hook, either auto generated by IRIS or provided by the module itself.

type.description: Type of data processed by the hook (ioc, asset, etc)

targets.description: List of objects ID of type "type" to process

data.name: abusive-content:spam
data.description: Spam or ‘unsolicited bulk e-mail’, meaning that the recipient has not granted verifiable permission for the message to be sent and that the message is sent as part of a larger collection of messages, all having identical content.

data.name: abusive-content:harmful-speech
data.description: Discretization or discrimination of somebody (e.g. cyber stalking, racism and threats against one or more individuals) May be found on a forum, email, tweet etc…

data.name: abusive-content:violence
data.description: Any Child pornography, glorification of violence, may be found on a website, forum, email, tweet etc…

data.name: malicious-code:virus
data.description: Malicious code that replicate itself and infects the computer and files;

data.name: malicious-code:worm
data.description: Malware that self-replicates and spread itself to other computers in the network without any user interaction;

data.name: malicious-code:ransomware
data.description: Ransomware is a type of malicious software from cryptovirology that blocks access to the victim's data or threatens to publish it until a ransom is paid.

data.name: malicious-code:trojan-malware
data.description: This category regroups many common malware types (Banking, POS, Mining malware).

data.name: malicious-code:spyware-rat
data.description: This category regroups malware types and tools that may have a bigger impact on the breached infrastructure and usually need further investigations (Common Spyware/Rat, State sponsored malwares, StealersHacking tool).

data.name: malicious-code:dialer
data.description: Computer program used to identify the phone numbers that can successfully make a connection with a computer modem. Use this category to classify overpriced SMS sent by malicious mobile application.

data.name: malicious-code:rootkit
data.description: Malware, which alter the standard functionality of an operating system in order to do its malicious actions in a stealthy way. In practice, Rootkits hijacks systems functions in order to alter the returning values to hide themselves from simple analysis tools.

data.name: information-gathering:scanner
data.description: Attacks that send requests to a system to discover weak points. This also includes some kinds of testing processes to gather information about hosts, services and accounts. Examples: fingerd, DNS querying, ICMP, SMTP (EXPN, RCPT,).

data.name: information-gathering:sniffing
data.description: Observing and recording network traffic (wiretapping).

data.name: information-gathering:social-engineering
data.description: Gathering information from a human being in a non-technical way (eg, lies, tricks, bribes, or threats).

data.name: intrusion-attempts:exploit-known-vuln
data.description: An attempt to compromise a system or to disrupt any service by exploiting vulnerabilities with a standardised identifier such as CVE name (eg, buffer overflow, backdoors, cross side scripting, etc).

data.name: intrusion-attempts:login-attempts
data.description: Multiple login attempts (guessing / cracking of passwords, brute force).

data.name: intrusion-attempts:new-attack-signature
data.description: An attempt using an unknown exploit.

data.name: intrusion:privileged-account-compromise
data.description: A successful full compromise of a system or application (service). This can have been caused remotely by a known or new vulnerability, but also by an unauthorized local access.

data.name: intrusion:unprivileged-account-compromise
data.description: A successful compromise of a system or application (service). This can have been caused remotely by a known or new vulnerability, but also by an unauthorized local access. The intruded did not achieve to escale his privileges locally.

data.name: intrusion:botnet-member
data.description: The compromised asset is also being part of a botnet. This is reserved mainly for public web servers. See malicious code in priority for workstations or internal server’s compromise. For example, phpmailer, etc…

data.name: intrusion:domain-compromise
data.description: The whole domain is compromised; this is commonly used for active directory and detected by a 'pass the ticket' attack or a discovery of 'ad dumps' files.

data.name: intrusion:application-compromise
data.description: An application is compromised; the attacker possess an uncontrolled access to data, server, and assets used by this application (CMDB, DB, Backend services, etc.).

data.name: availability:dos
data.description: An attacker attempts to prevent legitimate users from accessing information or services.

data.name: availability:ddos
data.description: Form of electronic attack involving multiple computers, which send repeated requests (HTTP requests, pings, TCP or UDP Flood) to a server to load it down and render the service inaccessible for a period of time.

data.name: availability:sabotage
data.description: Deliberate and malicious acts that result in the disruption of the normal processes and functions or the destruction or damage of equipment or information.

data.name: availability:outage
data.description: Unavailability of the system but done with no malice.

data.name: information-content-security:Unauthorised-information-access
data.description: Any access to unauthorized data. It may be access of data on improperly restricted server share or database exfiltered by using a SQLi.

data.name: information-content-security:Unauthorised-information-modification
data.description: Unauthorized tampering of data on files, documents or database.

data.name: fraud:copyright
data.description: Selling or installing copies of unlicensed commercial software or other copyright protected materials (Warez).

data.name: fraud:masquerade
data.description: Types of attacks in which one entity illegitimately assumes the identity of another in order to benefit from it. This attack may be used for president fraud requesting transactions.

data.name: fraud:phishing
data.description: Masquerading as another entity in order to persuade the user to reveal a private credential.

data.name: vulnerable:vulnerable-service
data.description: Open resolvers, world readable printers, vulnerability apparent from Nessus etc scans, virus, signatures not up to date, etc. This includes for example default SNMP community or default password on any application.

data.name: conformity:regulator
data.description: All lack about regulator rules (CSSF, GDPR, etc.).

data.name: conformity:standard
data.description: All lack about standards certification of the company (ISO27000, NIS, ISAE3402, etc.).

data.name: conformity:security-policy
data.description: All lack about the internal security policy of the company.

data.name: conformity:other-conformity
data.description: All lack that do not fit in one of previous categories should be put on this class.

data.name: other:other
data.description: All incidents that do not fit in one of the given categories should be put into this class. If the number of incidents in this category increases, it is an indicator that the classification scheme must be revised.
